ygData.subject: Re: Behavior characterization for agents in complex interactive environments
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, to me this kind of behavior characterization seems like the simplest and easiest to understand one. And simple things are often the best. :) I thought

Hi Ken,

to me this kind of behavior characterization seems like the simple=
st 
and easiest to understand one. And simple things are often the 
best. :=
) 
I thought about this issue you mention but it looks like there is no 
ge=
neral solution to it. Or I may be wrong. Since NS uses steady-state 
evolut=
ion, it can take advantage of real-time NEAT in the sense that 
all individ=
uals can be evaluated simultaneously and one is replaced 
each N ticks. In =
NERO you have a minimum time-to-live treshold, in 
order to distinguish ind=
ividuals that are properly evaluated, right? 
In my implementation I call t=
hese "Adults". So one way to prevent the 
blank behaviors is to let the ind=
ividual live as long as it does all 
possible actions at least once, then t=
he "Adult" switch is turned on 
(it is off at birth). But individuals that =
are genetically incapable 
of doing some actions could live forever, which =
can be a problem. 
However, this also means that they are already far into =
the behavior 
space and therefore can be considered very different behavior=
. So 
another "give up" constant can be introduced that kills off such 
beh=
aviors. 
In general, this is something similar to applying NS for a game of=
 
chance. Maybe a better solution is to have multiple trials for each 
indi=
vidual, to ensure it will meet at least most of the possible 
situations. 
=

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote=
:
>
> Peter, I like your idea for characterizing behavior in dynamic and
> =
interactive environments, and I think it makes good sense.  I'd be
> intere=
sted in seeing how well it works. 
> 
> One issue may be that some individu=
als simply never encounter the
> situations that others do.  Therefore, som=
e of the behavior
> characterization will be blank.  How do you think such =
blank areas 
can
> be rectified when comparing two individuals?  For exampl=
e, perhaps 
you
> took a right turn when you could, but I never encountered=
 an
> opportunity to turn right.  Do we consider this behavior different? 
=
> (I am assuming we would just ignore that dimension of behavior, but
> per=
haps you have another idea)  In general, I like your idea and 
think
> it s=
hould be an effective general approach.
> 
> It may also be possible to cha=
racterize behavior in more general
> terms.  Even though evaluation is inhe=
rently noisy, it is possible
> that a general characterization may filter o=
ut much noise.  For
> example, perhaps something like counting how many doo=
r an individual
> enters or how much food it eats could give a general sens=
e of its
> personality even though it would vary slightly in any given 
lif=
etime.
> 
> These are important issues if NS is to be used directly in an
>=
 interactive/coevolutionary world, so it's good to think about them.
> 
> k=
en
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@>=

> wrote:
> >
> > Hi all, 
> > 
> > I was thinking of how to characterize b=
ehavior of an agent in a 
> > complex dynamic world. As you all know, the 2=
D maze world in the 
> > demos is a static one. It doesn't interact with th=
e agent. Thus 
it is 
> > possible for Novelty Search to exploit the static=
 environment and 
> > develop behaviors that are not successful or meaningf=
ul on even 
> > slightly different maze configurations. I don't say that NS=
 
doesn't 
> > find general solutions able to navigate most mazes. I mean 
=
that "born 
> > to solve only this particular maze" solutions appear often.=
 
> > 
> > Further, what if I add more agents, in a realtime interavtive 
>=
 > environment like the one in NERO? While trying to generalize 
> > everyt=
hing I see in terms of behavior characterization, it was 
> > difficult to =
just say "the agent does this!" and use it as BC. It 
is 
> > because the r=
eal world environment is not static, it interacts 
with 
> > the agent, so =
it becomes something like noisy evaluation when I 
try 
> > to evolve one. =
The same individual could appear more and less 
novel 
> > every time. 
> >=
 
> > So one day, I was observing my dog.. Let's think of my dog as a 
> > =
complex biological agent in a real world interactive 
environment.. If 
> >=
 you try to make a summary of its behavior, how can you do it? One 
may 
> =
> suggest to put the dog in various situations and observe its 
> > reactio=
ns, finally collecting a summary of what it does in those 
> > situations. =
While this seems like the solution, it is not. 
Because in 
> > order to co=
mpare different dogs, you will have to put all of them 
> > through the sam=
e tests in order to avoid the noisy evaluation. 
And 
> > this brings us to=
 a static environment again, because we know 
what 
> > exactly is going to=
 happen to all agents, in order to see their 
> > reactions. While realizin=
g that, I arrived on a better idea that 
I am 
> > going to talk about now.=
 
> > 
> > In a complex interactive world, a little is known what exactly 
=
can 
> > happen to an agent. Further, the agent has a limited set of 
actio=
ns 
> > that it can take. A behavior characterization taking into account 
=
the 
> > actions only is not enough, because it is not known what happened =

to 
> > the agent before that action. So one solution I came up with is 
t=
his 
> > one. You have a list of all possible and/or performed actions for =

the 
> > BC. For each action, a summary or a more detailed list of 
situat=
ions 
> > must exist. So basically let's say that we have a simple robot 
t=
hat 
> > can go forward, fire a rocket and turn left/right. With 
rangefing=
er 
> > sensors or whatever. Instead of tracking only *what* it did 
during=
 
> > its lifetime, the system now has to track also in what 
circumstances=
 
> > the particular action took place, and add that to the summary of 
> >=
 behavior. This can be the inputs at that particular timestep, for 
> > exa=
mple. Or the relative positions of other agents that it may 
> > interact w=
ith. 
> > 
> > Does it make sense? Suppose you try to characterize a driver=
 in a 
> > city traffic conditions. Anything can happen. But if you also 
t=
rack 
> > what the driver *sees* in the particular moments when he acts, in=
 
> > addition to what actions he takes, it is a lot easier to 
distinguish=
 
> > between different driving behaviors.
> > 
> > I will be happy to hear=
 your thoughts about this. Perhaps it is 
> > nothing new, but I didn't see=
 any discussion about it. Though it 
is 
> > an important issue about how t=
o use Novelty Search for multi-
agent, 
> > coevolutionary, and some real-w=
orld applicatons. 
> > 
> > Peter
> >
>
